Authors:
Ramona Irimia , Oscar Alejandro Peréz, Marc
Gottschling
Title:
Strong biogeographic signal in the phylogenetic relationships
of Rochefortia Sw. (Ehretiaceae, Boraginales)
Keywords:
biogeography, Caribbean, cpDNA, ITS, molecular phylogeny,
taxonomy
Abstract:
Dioecious and thorny Rochefortia Sw. is a poorly known
though distinct element of the Ehretiaceae comprising woody plants
restricted to the Caribbean and the adjacent American mainland. The
approximately ten species display a great morphological variability and
overlapping taxonomic boundaries, which makes it difficult to
differentiate them (particularly in the Caribbean region). We
investigated the phylogenetic relationships of Rochefortia using DNA
sequence data from one nuclear locus (Internal Transcribed Spacer) and
three chloroplast DNA loci (rps16, trnLâ“trnF, trnSâ“trnG). The
monophyly of Rochefortia was confirmed, with a sister group relationship
between an American mainland clade and a Caribbean clade. The latter
segregates into three, morphologically rather variable lineages,
distributed either in the Lesser Antilles or in the eastern Greater
Antilles or in the western Greater Antilles. Thus, geographic occurrence
rather than morphology is indicative for taxonomic delimitation in
Rochefortia.
